question: [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [Input Validation] Are temp_file_path and target_db_path validated to be within expected directories, or can an attacker provide paths that cause extraction to system directories? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [Archive Format Validation] Does File::open() at line 105 validate the archive is actually a valid tar.gz file before extraction, or can a malformed file cause crashes or unexpected behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [All Functions] [Thread Safety] Are these functions thread-safe, or can concurrent invocations from multiple threads cause race conditions in filesystem operations leading to data corruption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [All Functions] [Locking Mechanism] Is there any file-level or directory-level locking to prevent concurrent access to the same database paths, or can parallel operations corrupt shared state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: rename_db_folders_and_cleanup()] [Atomicity Guarantee] On systems without atomic directory rename, can the rename operations be interrupted leaving the filesystem in an inconsistent state that can't be automatically recovered? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: create_tar_gz()] [Concurrent Reads] If the database is modified during tar archive creation by append_dir_all() at line 67, can this result in an archive containing an inconsistent snapshot that fails integrity checks on restore? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: create_tar_gz()] [CPU Exhaustion] Can compression of large databases consume excessive CPU time without yielding, causing validator to miss consensus deadlines and be penalized or removed from validator set? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [I/O Starvation] Can extraction of large archives with millions of small files starve other I/O operations, preventing the validator from processing transactions and causing temporary loss of liveness? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: create_tar_gz()] [Memory Pressure] Does holding the entire compressed archive in memory at line 79 cause memory pressure that triggers OS paging, dramatically slowing validator performance during backup operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [Disk I/O Amplification] Can malicious archives be crafted to maximize disk I/O operations (e.g., many small random writes) causing disk thrashing and validator performance degradation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: create_tar_gz()] [No Encryption] Are backup archives encrypted before storage, or can an attacker with access to backup storage locations read sensitive validator state including pending transactions or account data? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [No Authenticity Check] Does the restore process verify the archive's authenticity through digital signatures, or can an attacker perform substitution attacks replacing legitimate backups with malicious ones? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: create_tar_gz()] [Metadata Leakage] Can file metadata in tar archives leak sensitive information about validator configuration, database structure, or transaction patterns that aids targeted attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [Checksum Verification] Does tar extraction verify checksums for individual files, or can bit flips during storage/transmission cause silent data corruption in restored databases? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: rename_db_folders_and_cleanup()] [Windows Platform] On Windows systems where directory handles might be held open by anti-virus or backup software, can fs::rename() operations at lines 20 and 31 fail with access denied errors leaving the system in inconsistent state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [Case-Sensitive Filesystems] On case-insensitive filesystems like macOS, can archives containing files with names differing only in case cause extraction failures or file overwrites? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: create_tar_gz()] [Filesystem Limits] Can database paths exceeding filesystem maximum path length cause tar creation to fail silently or create truncated archives with data loss? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [Special Files] Does archive extraction properly handle special filesystem objects like device files, named pipes, or sockets that could be exploited for local privilege escalation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: rename_db_folders_and_cleanup()] [Network Filesystems] On network filesystems (NFS, SMB), are the rename operations still atomic, or can network latency create windows for race conditions and data corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: create_tar_gz()] [Information Disclosure] Do log messages at lines 61-65, 69, 85-90, 95 leak sensitive path information that could aid attackers in identifying validator configuration and mounting targeted attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: create_tar_gz()] [Insufficient Logging] Are failure cases logged with sufficient detail to enable forensic analysis after a security incident, or can attackers perform operations without detection? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [Missing Audit Trail] Does restore operation create audit logs with sufficient detail to track who initiated the restore and verify archive provenance, or can attackers restore malicious backups without detection? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Integration] [Time-of-Backup Attack] Can an attacker who compromises a validator briefly, create a malicious backup using create_tar_gz() that includes backdoored database files, which then gets distributed to other validators who restore it via unpack_tar_gz() spreading the compromise across the network? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Integration] [Rollback Attack] Can an attacker force restore of an old backup to revert blockchain state to a previous point, enabling double-spending by replaying transactions that were valid at that height but have since been spent? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/backup_restore/fs_ops.rs] [Function: unpack_tar_gz()] [Archive Substitution] During the window between File::open() at line 105 and archive.unpack() at line 108, can an attacker swap the archive file with a malicious version through a race condition, causing extraction of attacker-controlled data? (High)
